item.title: Zohran Mamdani and the Future of New York
item.description: Readers discuss Zohran Mamdani’s election as mayor of New York, and have plenty of advice for him. Also: Thoughts about exercise.

item.title: There Is No Cease-Fire in the West Bank
item.description: Violence in the occupied territories continues even if hostilities in Gaza have cooled.

item.title: One Horror of Slavery That Until Recently Could Not Be Told
item.description: The evil of human bondage was more complex than many historians care to reckon with.

item.title: A Little, Precious Seedling of Hope
item.description: Forget MAGA. Forget MAHA. Let’s make America sane again.

item.title: One of the Founders’ Worst Fears Has Been Realized
item.description: Trump has a favorite power.

item.title: Maurene Comey’s Case Is More Consequential Than Her Father’s
item.description: What James and Maurene Comey’s cases tell us about President Trump.

item.title: What the Movies Need From Sydney Sweeney
item.description: Only stardom can save Hollywood.

item.title: Democrats Need an Agenda Ahead of the 2026 Elections
item.description: Though G.O.P. members are more likely to be viewed as “extreme,” they trounce their opponents on who is more effective.

item.title: Mamdani and Wall Street Need Each Other
item.description: The threat from Washington is going to require teamwork.

item.title: From Here in Beijing, China Doesn’t Look So Strong
item.description: Despair about dimming economic and personal prospects has created an outwardly strong, inwardly brittle nation.

item.title: Mamdani’s Much Needed Vision for the Pro-Family City
item.description: Young people want a positive, urban vision of family.

item.title: I’m a Psychoanalyst. This Is What Technology Is Doing to Us.
item.description: We’ve lost the capacity to feel the grief technology brings.

item.title: Abortion Has Remained Mostly Accessible. That May Soon Change.
item.description: American women need the freedom to determine the course of their own lives.

item.title: The Promise of the Bronx River Parkway
item.description: A pioneering road shows what highways were and what they can be as it turns 100.

item.title: Mamdani and the Return of Inequality Politics
item.description: The central dynamic of American politics, underground for a decade, is back.

item.title: Tim Kaine on Why He Voted to End the Government Shutdown
item.description: Extending the government shutdown would not have worked.

item.title: Alex Karp Went From Biden Donor to Trump Enabler. Why?
item.description: A tech billionaire professes to hate identity politics, but they seem in some ways to consume him.

item.title: Trump and the Rising Cost of Health Care
item.description: Readers respond to news analysis articles about health care and the shutdown. Also: Art in new spaces; what A.I. isn’t.

item.title: Democrats Sure Taught Trump a Lesson
item.description: It’s one he is unlikely to forget.

item.title: Africa’s Important Role in a Post-Trump World
item.description: Lydia Polgreen speaks to the former New York Times bureau chief Howard W. French about the cost of not engaging with Africa.

item.title: Steve Bannon Thinks Zohran Mamdani Is a Genius. It’s Not a Feint.
item.description: Key elements of the mayor-elect’s campaign have enormous potential for a party that was badly beaten in 2024.

item.title: You’re a Computer Science Major. Don’t Panic About A.I.
item.description: We taught a generation how to write code. Now we need to teach future generations how to edit code.

item.title: From Apple to Meta: How Silicon Valley Lost Its Spine
item.description: The revolutionaries in Silicon Valley are no longer storming the gates. They’re inside the castle, polishing the silverware.

item.title: Cancer Patients Like Me Are Casualties of MAHA’s Hypocrisy
item.description: The Trump administration has undermined the once bipartisan war on cancer and declined to approve a promising melanoma therapy.

item.title: Chuck Schumer Is a Convenient Punching Bag, but He’s Not the Real Problem
item.description: The shutdown still may be a net gain for Democrats.

item.title: Meet the New Antisemites, Same as the Old Antisemites
item.description: A bigotry for morons will always be political gold in a world of morons.

item.title: On Veterans Day, This Is the Lonely, Terrible Sorrow We Must Never Forget
item.description: To imagine the cost of an “America First” policy, walk through World War II cemeteries in Europe.

item.title: Teaching History in the Trump Era
item.description: Readers respond to an article about how the teaching of U.S. history is changing. Also: Democratic pragmatism; emergency care at risk.

item.title: Iraq War Veterans, 20 Years Later
item.description: “I don’t know how to explain the war to myself,” says a veteran of the Iraq war. In 2003, they were sent to Iraq. Two decades later, veterans from the same unit grapple with their younger selves and try to make sense of the war. Watch the full Op-Docs film, “The Army We Had,” at nytimes.com/column/op-docs.

item.title: Use A.I. to Reinvigorate Democracy — Not Replace It
item.description: Governments shouldn’t hand over decision-making to A.I.

item.title: Welcome to Our New Era. What Do We Call It?
item.description: We have arrived at a “Polycene” moment where binary systems are giving way to multiple interconnected ones.

item.title: What Is Kennedy’s Problem With Medication?
item.description: Shaming people for being on medication is dangerous.

item.title: What Were Democrats Thinking?
item.description: This is how the shutdown ends?

item.title: A.I. Chatbots Should Be Legally Allowed to Keep Your Secrets
item.description: The case for “A.I. Interaction Privilege.”

item.title: What Even Is a ‘Good’ Job?
item.description: It starts with abandoning the fetish over manufacturing.

item.title: Make Medical School Three Years
item.description: Medicine shouldn’t be a career for the wealthy alone.

item.title: Democrats Didn’t Compromise on the Shutdown. They Collapsed.
item.description: Readers respond to the Democratic defection that may help end the shutdown. Also: The proposed Trump coin; seniors who downsize.

item.title: What Zohran Mamdani Understands About New York
item.description: Zohran Mamdani made the city glow, bringing a beauty to the everyday fixtures we ceased to register.

item.title: The New Democratic Brand
item.description: “The caricature of a national Democrat is weak, woke and whiny,” Michelle Cottle says on “The Opinions.” But last week’s election proved that Democrats are flipping that narrative — at least in places like Virginia, New Jersey and New York City.

item.title: Cruelty, Bigotry and Rage. What’s Not to Like?
item.description: This is what happens when the fringe becomes the mainstream (and vice versa).

item.title: Democratic Election Victories Show How to Beat Trump
item.description: Democratic election victories should kill the myth that Trumpism is invincible.

item.title: ‘We Have a Border for a Reason’
item.description: Cecilia Muñoz on how to solve America’s biggest political challenge.

item.title: A.I. Is on Its Way to Something Even More Remarkable Than Intelligence
item.description: Skeptics overlook how our concepts change.

item.title: Mamdani Isn’t the Future of the Democrats. This Guy Is.
item.description: The Democratic Party will not return to the White House, nor reclaim Congress, until it learns to embrace centrist politicians like Pennsylvania’s governor.

item.title: When Addiction Treatment Is Involuntary
item.description: Readers respond to a proposal in Utah to forcibly remove homeless people. Also: Stolen treasures; America’s gambling problem; why retire?

item.title: Do you take a GLP-1 for alternative uses? Tell us about it.
item.description: Some semaglutide users experience benefits beyond weight loss. Are you one of them?

item.title: America Isn’t Cool Anymore
item.description: Pop culture exports have long been a potent source of American soft power. What happens when the U.S. is no longer the global capital of cool?

item.title: What if the Monarchy Went Out With a Bang?
item.description: If all other institutions fail, is there not a certain unique potency in the monarchy before dissolution?

item.title: We Can’t Pretend to Know the Future of the Democratic Party
item.description: There is no one-size-fits-all template for winning elections.
